00022 // This is the "squish it into memory" version of ProbeLists.
00023 // example/example-ProbeListFactory.cpp has a examples of usage.

00052 
00053 // Limits of what can be stored.
00054 #define PROBELIST_BLOCK_CNT_MAX  UINT_MAX
00055 #define PROBELIST_PROBE_CNT_MAX  UINT_MAX
00056 #define PROBELIST_NAME_LEN_MAX   USHRT_MAX
00057 
00058 #ifdef __GNUC__
00059 #define PROBELIST_PACKED __attribute__ ((packed))
00060 #else
00061 #define PROBELIST_PACKED
00062 #endif
00063 
00064 // Set needed features for sparcs.  They cant do unaligned loads.
00065 #ifdef __sparc__
00066 #define PROBELIST_NEEDS_UNALIGNED
00067 #endif
00068 
00069 // For testing you might want to uncomment this even on a
00070 // machine which does support unaligned reads.
00071 // #define PROBELIST_NEEDS_UNALIGNED
00072 
00073 // These macros are for abstracting out where unaligned accesses are happening.
00074 // Be sure to match up the sizes of access with the sizes of the elements.
00075 #ifdef PROBELIST_NEEDS_UNALIGNED
00076 
00077 // This arch cant to unaligned stores and loads, so
00078 // we need some helper functions to build the value from bytes.
00079 // NOTE: These are all big-endian
00080 unsigned int probelist_load32b(unsigned int* p);
00081 unsigned short probelist_load16b(unsigned short* p);
00082 void probelist_store32b(unsigned int* p,unsigned int v);
00083 void probelist_store16b(unsigned short* p,unsigned short v);
00084 
00085 // Now use them when we have possibly unaligned accesses.
00086 #define PROBELIST_LOAD32B(p)    probelist_load32b((unsigned int*)p)
00087 #define PROBELIST_STORE32B(p,v) probelist_store32b((unsigned int*)(p),v)
00088 //
00089 #define PROBELIST_LOAD16B(p)    probelist_load16b((unsigned short*)p)
00090 #define PROBELIST_STORE16B(p,v) probelist_store16b((unsigned short*)(p),v)
00091 
00092 #else
00093 
00094 // This arch can do unaligned loads, so just deref the pointer
00095 #define PROBELIST_LOAD32B(p) (*(p))
00096 #define PROBELIST_LOAD16B(p) (*(p))
00097 //
00098 #define PROBELIST_STORE32B(p,v) *(p)=(v)
00099 #define PROBELIST_STORE16B(p,v) *(p)=(v)
00100 
00101 #endif
00102 
00103 //
00104 #define PROBELIST_LOAD8B(p)    (*(p))
00105 #define PROBELIST_STORE8B(p,v) *(p)=(v)
00106 
00107 // This has to be allocated from a ProbeListHeap as it does
00108 // not free memory on allocation.
00109 // But we could search the regions to see if we could find our
00110 // pointer in the Factory and if not, free our memory.
00111 
00112 /** \page file-format-spf File Format: SPF (NON-OFFICIAL-RELEASE)
00113 
00114 Simple Probe Format (SPF) is a text representation of the probes for a particular
00115 probeset as stored in a ProbeList class. The intention is that spf will describe
00116 the structure of a probeset and that an additional information about probes
00117 (i.e. gc content, genomic position, pcr fragment size, etc.) will be provided in
00118 another file. The additional information is not to be included in the spf file
00119 as 1) it would make the file much larger to have every possible additional field
00120 and 2) given the innovation in both assay and algorithm development it is
00121 impossible to predict all the fields that may be necessary so providing them in
00122 an additional file allows them to by dynamic and flexible. The program
00123 cdf-to-simple will convert cdf files and pgf/clf files into the spf format.
00124 
00125 The file starts off with the obligatory header lines of chip_type,
00126 num-probesets, num-cols and num-rows with a preceding '#%%' to indicate that the
00127 line is a header line. Other header lines containing meta information are
00128 permitted, but not required. After the header lines there is a single, tab
00129 delimited, line that supplies the names of each column (more below on what each
00130 column contains).  For example the HG-U133 array header would look like:
00131 
00132 <pre>
00133 #%spf-format=1
00134 #%%chip_type=HG-U133_Plus_2
00135 #%%num-probesets=54675
00136 #%%num-cols=1164
00137 #%%num-rows=1164
00138 name    type    num_blocks      block_sizes     block_annotations       num_match       num_probes      probes
00139 </pre>
00140 
00141 
00142 Following this the bulk of the data is in the form of 8 tab delimited columns:
00143 
00144  - name - The name (sometimes called id) for a particular probeset. Examples
00145    include '1552314_a_at' from the U133 designs or 'SNP_A-4282894' from the 500K
00146    Sty array. [string]
00147 
00148  - type - The type of probeset as defined by ProbeSet::Type
00149    (Unknown=0, Expression=1, Genotype=2, Copynumber=5) [int]
00150 
00151  - num_blocks - How many blocks (also known as groups) are in the
00152    probeset. Expression and Copynumber probesets have a single block while
00153    Genotyping probesets have 2 (on per allele) or 4 (one per strand and allele
00154    combination) [int]
00155 
00156  - block_sizes - Comma separated list of the number of perfect match (PM) probes
00157    in each block. [ints]
00158 
00159  - block_annotations - Comma separated list with one annotation per
00160    block. Annotations are defined in the ProbeSet::BlockAnnotation
00161    enumeration. [ints]
00162 
00163  - num_match - How many matching probes are there for each PM probe in the
00164    probeset? If PM only probeset this will be 1 (the PM itself). If a probeset
00165    has mismatch (MM) probes then num_match will be 2. In theory for resequencing
00166    arrays this would be 4, but resequencing probesets are not supported. [int]
00167 
00168  - num_probes - Total number of probes present in the probeset. This value
00169    should be equal to the sum of the block_sizes multiplied by the num_match
00170    field. [int]
00171 
00172  - probes - Comma separated list of probe indexes into the array. Indexes are
00173    the same 1 based indexes as used in the Bioconductor affy package. This is
00174    equivalent to the FusionCELData::XYToIndex() function result with 1 added to
00175    each index. The XYToIndex() function calculates the index as (y*c) + x where
00176    y is the y coordinate of a probe, x is the x coordinate of the probe on the
00177    array and c is the number of columns on the array. For example to get the
00178    correct index for a SNP6 chip (2572 rows and 2680 cols) the index for probe
00179    at position x=1000, y=500 is 1 + (500 * 2680 + 1000) = 1341001. The value
00180    '-1' is used to represent the 'null probe' which indicates no probe for that
00181    place. Examples of the null probe usage include a probeset with only MM probes
00182    or where only certain PM probes have matching MM probes. [ints]
00183 
00184 Lets look at a couple of examples to see what to expect. The simplest case is a
00185 PM-only expression probeset:
00186 <pre>
00187 3394979 1       1       4       0       1       4       797737,3775011,1875296,4778657
00188 </pre>
00189 
00190 The probeset's name is: '3394979' and it has a single block with 4 PM probes
00191 797737,3775011,1875296,4778657 that are used to generate a summary estimate.
00192 
00193 Things get slightly more interesting when we look at an example of a HG-U133 probeset like '200090_at':
00194 <pre>
00195 200090_at       1       1       11      0       2       22      1146869,424878,458233,325661,1187125,387873,765617,614181,879885,358159,48602,1148033,426042,459397,326825,1188289,389037,766781,615345,881049,359323,49766
00196 </pre>
00197 
00198 Here again there is just one block, but now the probeset contains mismatches so
00199 the num_match field is '2'. Conceptually the first half of the probe list is PM
00200 probes and the second half is the MM probes in the matching order. This is
00201 illustrated in Figure 1. So probes [1146869,424878,..,358159,48602] are the PM
00202 probes and probes [1148033,426042,..,359323,49766] are the MM probes for this
00203 probeset.  Since they are in the same order the PM probe 1146869 has the
00204 corresponding MM probe 1148033. In fact the MM probe is always just one row away
00205 which means that the abs(PM index - MM index) = 1164 for this design as the PM
00206 probes were designed to be near the matching MM probes.
00207 
00208 @image html pm-mm-matching.png "Figure 1: Layout of PM and MM probes in the ProbeList."
00209 
00210 Genotyping probesets make extensive use of the blocks (aka groups), with a different block
00211 for each allele and sometimes for each strand. Looking at the GenomeWideSNP_6 probeset 'SNP_A-1999704' we see:
00212 <pre>
00213 SNP_A-1999704   2       2       3,3     1,2     1       6       756318,104506,6862022,756317,104505,6862021
00214 </pre>
00215 
00216 The probeset only has PM probes, but now there are two blocks. One block is for
00217 the A allele and the other is for the B allele. In this case each block has three
00218 probe indexes with the A allele being the first three and the B allele probes
00219 being the second three. The 500K probesets often have 4 blocks with a separate block
00220 for the A allele forward strand and A allele reverse strand. Looking at 'SNP_A-4246078' as
00221 an example:
00222 <pre>
00223 SNP_A-4246078   2       4       2,2,4,4 3,4,5,6 2       24      4595060,1345852,5001712,1549918,1737600,613594,849516,1535644,4217526,3887116,852076,5702732,4595061,1345853,5001713,1549919,1737601,613595,849517,1535645,4217527,3887117,852077,5702733
00224 </pre>
00225 
00226 This probeset has 4 blocks with the first two blocks interrogating the forward
00227 strand and the next two blocks interrogating the reverse strand. This probeset
00228 also contains mismatches as the num_match field is 2. Note that the block sizes
00229 and annotations only described for the PM portion of the probelist. The
00230 association of MM probes to the blocks is determined by which PM probe they are
00231 mapped to. Figure 2 has a graphical representation of this structure.
00232 
00233 @image html probelist-blocks.png "Figure 2: Blocks within the ProbeList"
00234

00325 
00326 There are three versions of the spf file format.  We refer
00327 to them as "v1", "v2" and "v3".  The spf-v1 format was
00328 described above.  The v2 and v3 formats are extensions of
00329 spf to add allele and context codes to SPF.
00330 
00331 While the formats can be identified by the column names, we
00332 suggest putting in a meta-data header "#%spf-format=X" so
00333 the readers can quickly check the format of the file.  If
00334 there isnt an "spf-format" header the format is assumed to
00335 be "1".
00336 
00337 The v2 format has the two columns added to the v1 format:
00338 "block_alleles" and "block_contexts".  Both of these columns
00339 are comma seperated list of values of the same length as
00340 num_blocks.  These values are used to populate the
00341 allele_code and context code of each probelist block.  The
00342 advantage of this format is it is compatable with the v1
00343 format, the extra fields can be ignored if the sw doesnt
00344 need them.
00345 
00346 The v3 format restructures the file do away with the comma
00347 seperated list of values.  By placing the blocks and probes
00348 onto seperate lines grouped by indentation, the SPF file is
00349 eaiser to modify.  Blocks and probeids can be commented out
00350 without having to count the commas in a long list.
00351 
00352 <pre>
00353 #%spf-format=3
00354 #%header0=name type
00355 #%header1=allele allele_code [allele_bases]
00356 #%header2=context context_code annotation
00357 #%header3=probes
00358 </pre>
00359 
00360 The "allele" and "context" columns always have the value
00361 "allele" and "context".  Their purpose is to act as a guide
00362 for humans who are looking at the file.  The column
00363 "allele_bases" are the bases that allele represents, it is
00364 only for checking the conversion. The other fields are the
00365 same as their comma seperated versions.
00366 
00367 To look at some example data from the DMET SPF file:
00368 
00369 <pre>
00370 #%spf-format=3
00371 #%header0=name type
00372 #%header1=allele allele_code allele_bases
00373 #%header2=context context_code annotation
00374 #%header3=probes
00375 DM3A10001       1
00376         allele  0       A
00377                 context 0       0
00378                         1145888
00379                         173152
00380                         277766
00381       [...more...]
00382                 context 1       0
00383                         1257548
00384                         1259122
00385                         312266
00386       [...more...]
00387                 context 2       0
00388                         1680942
00389                         1682516
00390                         176300
00391       [...more...]
00392         allele  1       C
00393                 context 0       0
00394                         1145887
00395                         173151
00396                         277765
00397       [...more...]
00398                 context 1       0
00399                         1257547
00400                         1259121
00401                         312265
00402       [...more...]
00403                 context 2       0
00404                         1680941
00405                         1682515
00406                         176299
00407       [...more...]
00408 </pre>
00409 
00410 The v3 format is oriented to DMET data, which has an allele
00411 and context focus.  The v4 format of the SpfFile has a block
00412 focus.  The fields related to each block appear after the
00413 filler text "block".  (Which, again, is just filler text for
00414 humans to read.)  This makes block-level hand edits eaiser
00415 than the v3 format.
00416 
00417 These columns have the same meaning as they do in the other
00418 spf formats.  (The data is the same, it is just the
00419 arrangement which has changed.) One item which is missing is
00420 the probe count for each block; The count is implict in the
00421 number of probes which follow.
00422 
00423 The "spf-format","chip_type", "num-cols", "num-rows" headers
00424 are required.  The "num-channels" is not required but
00425 defaults to "1" if not present.
00426 
00427 Here is an example v4 file:
00428 
00429 <pre>
00430 #%spf-format=4
00431 #%chip_type=Axiom_GW_Hu_SNP
00432 #%num-cols=1190
00433 #%num-rows=1190
00434 #%num-probesets=636352
00435 #%num-channels=2
00436 #%header0=name  type    num_match
00437 #%header1=      block   annotation      allele_code     context_code    channel_code    rep_type
00438 #%header2=              probe_id
00439 AFFX-LCP-11715001       9       1
00440         block   0       0       0       0       3
00441                 98058
00442                 98454
00443                 333283
00444                 333876
00445                 567911
00446                 568504
00447 AFFX-LCP-11715002       9       1
00448         block   0       0       0       1       3
00449                 98060
00450                 98456
00451                 333285
00452                 333878
00453                 567913
00454                 568506
00455 </pre>
00456 
00457 */
00458 
00459 /**
00460  * ProbeList class contains information about a group of probes that are going
00461  * to be analyzed together. Should have a 1-1 relationship with the ubiquitous
00462  * notion of a probe set in Affymetrix nomenclature. Class is essentially a list
00463  * of probe ids that should be processed together and the type of ProbeList
00464  * determines how that list should be viewed. There is a notion of a "blocks"
00465  * (aka groups from cdf file) and block annotations that should be analyzed
00466  * together (for example different alleles for genotyping are represented by
00467  * different blocks). If there are mismatches for perfect match probes the
00468  * numMatch field is set to '2' and the list is conceptually divided in half
00469  * with the PM probes in the first half and MM in the second half with the PM/MM
00470  * probes matches by position.  For example the first PM probe in the list
00471  * corresponds to the first MM probe found just after the halfway point in the
00472  * list. There is a notion of a 'null_probe' placeholder in case you have a
00473  * ProbeList of all MM probes (yes it happens) or a probeset where some PM
00474  * probes have matching MM and others don't. An additional class for probe level
00475  * data (i.e. probe info class) is planned for cases where specific probe level
00476  * information is needed for a particular application. This avoids cluttering up
00477  * ProbeList with information that will only be used in specialized
00478  * applications.
00479  *
00480  * A little history: Most of Affy's chips come with a cdf or pgf file that
00481  * document which probes should be analyzed together. To have a common datatype
00482  * to use across arrays the ProbeSet/Atom/Probe classes were born. ProbeSet and
00483  * Probe are pretty obvious and Atom is conceptually a PM/MM pair of probes that
00484  * should be analyzed together (or even more for a resequencing array, but those
00485  * were never supported). That worked fine for a while, but the nested nature of
00486  * the ProbeSet data type and the fact that newer designs don't have MM probes
00487  * makes it very inefficient in terms of RAM usage.
00488  *
00489  * This brings us to the ProbeList class which is very compact in memory
00490  * (especially with a custom heap for contiguous memory allocation). Here a
00491  * block of memory is allocated and there data is just offsets into the
00492  * array. This avoids any vectors and their wasted space. The design is also
00493  * amenable to memory mapping as everything is contiguous in memory rather than
00494  * a nested data structure.
00495  */
00496 
00497 //////////
00498 
00499 //////////
00500 
00501 //////////
00502 
00503 // ProbeList Block elements.
00504 struct ProbeList_E_Block {
00505   int     m_blockSize;
00506   short   m_blockAnn;
00507   char    m_blockAllele;
00508   char    m_blockContext;
00509   char    m_blockChannel;
00510   char    m_blockRepType;
00511 } PROBELIST_PACKED;
00512 
00513 // ProbeList Probe elements
00514 struct ProbeList_E_Probe {
00515   int    m_probeId;
00516   char   m_probeGc;
00517 } PROBELIST_PACKED;
00518 
00519 // The head of a ProbeList
00520 // the sizes here allow us to compute the offsets of the Block and Probe elements.
00521 struct ProbeList_Head {
00522   unsigned int m_type;
00523   unsigned int m_numMatch;
00524   // int   m_block_size; // we wont allow later additions. size==cnt
00525   // int   m_probe_size; // ditto for probes
00526   unsigned int   m_block_cnt;
00527   unsigned int   m_probe_cnt;
00528   /// the AnalysisProbeId (apid) of the 0th probe of this ProbeList
00529   /// Apids are assigned as the probes and blocks are added to the ProbeListFactory.
00530   /// Thus, the apids dont equal the probeIds; Even in the case of a single-channel design.
00531   unsigned int   m_apid_start;
00532   // char* name is right at the end of the elements
00533   // length of the name buffer (including the 0)
00534   unsigned short m_name_len;
00535 } PROBELIST_PACKED;
00536 
00537 // If ProbeListPacked were descended from ProbeList we would have
00538 // :public ProbeList
00539 // here.  It isnt as that would make it one pointer bigger.
00540 // Its current size is one pointer.

00614 /*                  "Head pointer is NULL."); */

00683 // A region of allocation for ProbeListPacked.
00684 // No need to pack the fields of a region as there arent that many of them,
00685 // as compared to ProbeListPacked.
00686 struct ProbeListFactory_Region {
00687   char* m_start_ptr;  ///< start of malloced region
00688   char* m_fill_ptr;   ///< where the next alloc will happen
00689   char* m_end_ptr;    ///< end of the memory region. (Dont go beyond here.)
00690 };
00691 
00692 /// A Factory for allocating and retrieving ProbeListPacked objects.
00693 /// It really should be called ProbeListPackedFactory or PackedProbeListFactory.
00694 class ProbeListFactory {
00695 public:
00696   /// regions which this factory has available to fill.
00697   std::vector<ProbeListFactory_Region> m_region;
00698   /// current region in which allocations will occur.
00699   unsigned int m_ridx;
00700   /// how big should automaticly allocated regions be?
00701   int m_default_region_size;
00702   /// keep track of the number of allocations for usage info.
00703   unsigned int m_allocs;
00704 
00705   /// Pointers to the start of each Probelist in our regions.
00706   std::vector<ProbeListPacked> m_probelist_vec;
00707 
00708   // from the spf file
00709   std::vector<std::string> m_chipTypes;
00710 
00711   // data we remember to read from and put into an spf file.
00712   int m_numCols; // X
00713   int m_numRows; // Y
00714   int m_numChannels;
00715 
00716   int getXYsize() { return m_numCols * m_numRows; };
00717 
00718   /// these are mutable as we lazily sort when needed.
00719   /// A vector of indexes sorted by name.
00720   mutable std::vector<int> m_name2idx_vec;
00721   /// Is the vector currenly sorted? (So we dont have to sort each time.)
00722   mutable bool m_name2idx_issorted;
00723   mutable int m_name2idx_sortcnt;
00724 
00725   ///
00726   mutable std::vector<int>* m_probeid2apid_vecptr;
00727 
00728   /// the total number of probes in this factory.
00729   /// this is used to assign AnalysisProbeIds as probes are added.
00730   unsigned int m_probecnt_total;
00731

00734   ~ProbeListFactory();
